unnormalised: Someone asked me about time zones, so here's my take! Trying to coordinate meetings across India can be a real pain. Like, I’m in Kolkata (IST), and my cousin’s studying in the US (EST). He always forgets the time difference. He’ll call me at 11:00 PM EST thinking it’s a reasonable time. It’s like, dude, it's 8:30 AM here! Prepone or postpone, doesn't matter, someone's always gonna be sleepy.
normalised: Someone asked me about time zones, so here is my take! Trying to coordinate meetings across India can be a real pain. Like, I am in Kolkata (I-S-T), and my cousin is studying in the U-S (E-S-T). He always forgets the time difference. He will call me at eleven P-M E-S-T thinking it is a reasonable time. It is like, dude, it is eight thirty A-M here! Prepone or postpone, does not matter, someone is always going to be sleepy.

unnormalised: And it's not just the US. Even within India, things get complicated. My company has offices in Mumbai and Guwahati. Mumbai is obviously IST, but scheduling calls for the Guwahati team can be tricky sometimes. We try to start meetings by 11:00 AM so that everyone can attend without staying up too late or starting too early. Trying to set up a conference call at 2:00 PM in Kolkata for colleagues in London (GMT) once resulted in absolute chaos since the person in London forgot DST.
normalised: And it is not just the U-S. Even within India, things get complicated. My company has offices in Mumbai and Guwahati. Mumbai is obviously I-S-T, but scheduling calls for the Guwahati team can be tricky sometimes. We try to start meetings by eleven A-M so that everyone can attend without staying up too late or starting too early. Trying to set up a conference call at two P-M in Kolkata for colleagues in London (G-M-T) once resulted in absolute chaos since the person in London forgot D-S-T.

unnormalised: Basically, keep a world clock handy and double-check everything before you schedule anything! I usually use some online converter to make sure, coz my brain just can't handle the calculations at 6:00 in the morning. Even then, mistakes happen. Just yesterday I almost missed a webinar at 10:00 because I converted it to a weird time. Moral of the story: Time zones are the bane of my existence.
